body.p: WebHelp Responsive output can be configured to work with multiple search engines.

The WebHelp Responsive plugin comes with a built-in JS based search engine configured by default. This search engine is recommended for a small or medium-sized documentation, offering a fairly good set of features such as sorting results by relevance, 5-star rating mechanism, custom rules for element scoring.

In addition to the embedded JS search engine, the WebHelp Responsive output can be easily configured to use the Oxygen Feedback search engine. This is a more advanced search engine, suitable for large documentations, and with a wider range of features: semantic search, faceted search or labels search.
A general comparison between client-side and server-side search processes:

dd.p: A client-side search process has the following characteristics:

ol.li: Runs in the user's web browser
Can be slower and less efficient than server-side searching, especially for large amounts of content
Requires downloading the entire search index to the user's device, which can be a burden for slower connections or limited devices
Can be limited by the resources available on the user's device, such as processing power and memory

dd.p:
On the other hand, the server-side search process:
Runs on a server, typically hosted by the application provider
Can be faster and more efficient than client-side searching, especially for large amounts of content
Requires server-side infrastructure, which can be more complex to implement and maintain
Returns only the relevant search results to the user's web browser, reducing the amount of data that needs to be downloaded
Is not limited by the resources available on the user's device, as the server can scale to handle large amounts of content

body.p: If none of the above options represent a choice, then the WebHelp Responsive transformation can be configured to work with other external search engines like Google search engine.
